item.title: Recession Depression
item.description: The Fed Hike is on. Soon comes slow growth in an inflationary environment
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Roch-Decter, CFA
item.content:encoded:
Hi Everyone 👋,

Welcome to the subscribers who have joined this week. If you’re reading this but haven’t subscribed, join our community of +55k smart, fun & edgy investors 👇

Subscribe now

*This is sponsored advertising content.

The time period we’re in can be summed up with the 3 R’s:

Russia, Rates, Recession.

On Tuesday, ahead of the Fed meeting, forecasters raised their chances for a coming recession from 23% to 33% in the next twelve months and boosted inflation targets. The chance of a recession in Europe stands at 50%.

On Wednesday, JPow took the floor and raised rates by the expected 25bps. He also had a somewhat dovish tone when looking to achieve a “soft landing”. Exactly how this is achieved will determine whether we creep into recession or not.

Whenever the word recession comes up, Gen Z will think of Covid destroying their Robinhood accounts, Millenials will think of how the subprime mortgage collapse affected their vanguard ETFs and Boomers will laugh as they went through dotcom, the early 90s interest rate run, and the Iranian Oil crisis (early 80s).

But what exactly is a recession, how long do they usually last, and is it all doom and gloom?

What impacts do exacerbated inflation and tightening monetary policy have?

This week, in <5 minutes, we’ll cover the:

  • The Definition of a Recession 👉 What it is, how it affects us, stagflation

  • History of Recessions 👉 How often they happen, how long they last

  • The Role of Interest Rates 👉 Curbing inflation without dampening growth

  • How do Stocks Perform? 👉 In a recession, in a rate hike environment

Let’s get started!

1. The Definition of a Recession 👉 What it is, how it affects us, stagflation

The National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER) defines a recession as "a significant decline in economic activity spread across the economy, lasting more than two quarters, normally visible in real gross domestic product (GDP), real income, employment, industrial production, and wholesale-retail sales”

It used to be defined just as two consecutive quarters of GDP decline, now the definition is a bit more broad-based, unlike the hardline on bull and bear markets (20%). Either way, recession = bad.

During recessions, businesses experience declining economic performance, real income (nominal - inflation) falls, real (nominal - inflation) GDP, and so on…

Notice a common variable when calculating real income and GDP. Both metrics are inflation-adjusted. We’ve written at length about the spike in commodities as well as strangled supplied chains and the effect that these things have on rising inflation.

So that real metric starts to struggle when inflation is so high.

Recessions may sound like doom and gloom, but they are a healthy part of every business cycle and take place after expansion.

Prolonged periods of expansion need time for digestion as the credit market expands and contracts. Many economists pile into a room and try to assess leading and lagging indicators to see where we are in the business cycle, but none can predict massive black swan events like Covid or War.

Nonetheless, helpful indicators like ISM’s Purchasing Managers Index, the shape of the yield curve, jobs numbers, CPI readings, and the OECD Composite Leading Indicator are useful tools in seeing just where we are at.

Recessions affect everyone because they hit you right in the wallet. It’s harder to get a job, groceries cost more, cars cost more, and gas costs more…

Barstool Sports @barstoolsports
Picked a tough week to take an RV trip @BussinWTB (via ig:rileyfit1)

March 15th 2022

516 Retweets5,192 Likes

The end result is a worse-off consumer and worse-off business. But just how often do recessions happen?

Under the Radar

PLANT-BASED MARKET POTENTIAL. US wholesale foodservice sales of plant-based meat grew 37% in 2020 and are expected to grow at a CAGR of 13% through 2028. Very Good Food Co. is positioned to capitalize by making plant-based foods fun, tasty, and accessible (at SCALE), through a combination of proven R&D and manufacturing know-how*!

SIGNIFICANT UPSIDE, NO DILUTION. With over $2B in projects including a $480M real estate project, a $550M solar project in Alberta, and a $1B+ solar project in the Caribbean, Greenbriar Capital is the most undervalued company in the real estate, ESG, and solar energy universe*!

CELLULAR AGRICULTURE INVESTING. Access to cellular agriculture startups is currently limited to ultra-high net worth individuals and private venture funds. CULT Food Science is on a mission to change that by becoming North America’s first mainstream cellular agriculture investment platform. The platform currently consists of 15 portfolio companies that represent the future of food*!

DIGITAL HEALTHCARE REVOLUTION. CloudMD is an integrated healthcare platform built to scale. With a $185M revenue run rate and a cash position of $60M, it's well positioned as a leader in the digital healthcare space! Its network already covers over 5M lives, 5,500 employer clients, and more than 7,500 mental health professionals and the Company has partnered with some significant players like Sun Life, Accenture, Empire Life and Medavie Blue Cross to name a few*.

SUSTAINABILITY MARKETPLACE BUILT TO SCALE. In just 14 short months since launch, Vejii has shown tremendous growth and become a digital powerhouse in the plant-based and sustainable living space! With a marketplace built for rapid scale, it just reported record revenue for January with a YoY increase of over 1,100%*!

2. History of Recessions 👉 How often they happen, how long they last

There have been as many as 48 recessions in the history of the United States. Cyclical volatility of GDP and unemployment was far greater before the great depression than it was after WWII, so these businesses cycles used to shift much more quickly.

Before the COVID-19 recession began in March 2020, no post-World War II era had come anywhere near the depth of the Great Depression, which lasted from 1929 until 1941 (and included a bull market between 1933-1937) and was caused by the 1929 stock market crash, among other factors.

When you think about going back hundreds of years to properly build out a data sample size, you quickly realize just how new to all of these we are. The NBER does not date any recessions before 1857, and even in the early 1900s data sets were extremely scarce because we did not have all the information.

Major modern economic statistics, such as unemployment and GDP, were not compiled on a regular and standardized basis until after WWII. So we’ve been doing this for less than 100 years which is a scary thought.

Let’s take a look at the most recent recessions and the reasons leading to them. Some are familiar, others less-so (might need to click to zoom in on this one)

So eight recessions since the 70s. Seems like a healthy part of the business cycle.

Before we continue, let’s check in with our Outrageous Chartered FinMEME Analyst Dr. Patel!

3. The Role of Interest Rates 👉 Curbing inflation without dampening growth

Ray Dalio has a phenomenal video on YouTube titled “How the Economic Machine Works”

In it, he describes economic cycles driven by productivity, long-term credit cycles, and short-term credit cycles. Interest rates act as a temperature gauge during credit cycles.

During periods where income levels are rising, asset levels are going up, and the stock market is ripping higher - people start to binge on spending. This causes inflation to run wild. Add to that bottlenecks in the supply chain and geopolitical conflict and it heats up even more.

However... the black swan event of a global pandemic really slowed global economic growth. Supply chains were ground down to a halt overnight.

We know that the fed has two jobs: control prices and control employment. With prices and inflation running hot, the only viable conclusion that you can make is interest rates going up.

However, what needs to occur is what’s called a soft landing. Key to this is the ability to increase rates to curb inflation, but not raise rates so fast that GDP growth is choked off by high borrowing costs.

4. How do Stocks Perform 👉 In a recession, in a rate hike environment

Although the optics of recessionary periods look bad, we have to follow the famous saying, “Be fearful when others are greedy, and greedy while others are fearful.”

If we look at the S&P performance in periods coming out of a recession, it proved to be a great dip-buying opportunity:

What we are also about to enter is a Fed rate hike cycle. Back in November, a massive sell-off materialized around speculative technology. If we look at tech stocks by growth cohort we have seen very drastic multiple compression:

A lot of capital flooded out of the system when fear of increasing rates hit, but the question to answer now is: how much of this is now already priced in? When we look at which specific sectors perform well during rate-hike cycles, we’ve actually seen technology companies make the best recovery:

And as for the very high inflation readings, it is also not all doom and gloom when it comes to equity performance:

Wrapping Up…

These are incredibly volatile and interesting times, as we’ve seen with commodities, Chinese internet companies, the “profitless tech” basket, and so on…

But we have to always keep calm, stick to fundamentals, and weather the storm. I don’t believe a recession is on the horizon, but one of the best strategies to have during a recession (if it were to occur) is to invest in companies with low debt, good cash flow, and strong balance sheets. Conversely, avoid companies that are highly leveraged, cyclical, or speculative.

Until next time. Always Yours. Incessantly Chasing ROI,

-Genevieve Roch-Decter, CFA

P.S. Have you subscribed to our *NEW* CRYPTO NEWSLETTER?

GRIT CRYPTO

#1 FREE Finance Newsletter on Substack. GRIT launches a PAID CRYPTO newsletter. After reaching a record $3 trillion in 2021, the market has pulled back ~40%. We believe NOW is the BEST time to go hunting for opportunities!
By Genevieve Roch-Decter, CFA

What else we Grittin’ On?

WHY SO SERIOUS? The Michigan Consumer Sentiment index fell for the 5th time in 6 months in March. Sentiment is at an 11-year low.

EU GIVES A-OK TO AMAZON. Antitrust regulators in the European Union signed off on Amazon's $8.5B purchase of MGM. Amazon's final hurdle is the Federal Trade Commission (FTC).

BIG W FOR PELOSI & CO. The hearing to consider the proposed banning of congressional stock-trading has been postponed. Hopefully Nancy got her trades in before the rally!

NICKEL MARKET MESS. The London Metal Exchange reopened on Wednesday but trading had to be halted within minutes due to new glitches. The LME had previously been shut down for a week.

WHAT ARE YOU GOING TO DO NOW? Former Disney CEO Robert Iger is taking his talent to the metaverse. Iger joins the board of metaverse startup Genies Inc.

item.title: AMC buys a gold mine...wait what?
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Roch-Decter, CFA
item.content:encoded:
*This is sponsored advertising content.

Happy Friday Everyone! 👋

Remember, people who succeed in the stock market also accept periodic losses, setbacks, and unexpected occurrences. Big drops do not scare them out of the game.

MARKET UPDATE

Triple Witching today

  • Expiration of:

    • single-stock options

    • futures on stock indexes

    • options on stock indexes

9 a.m. Biden/Xi meeting

  • Biden warning of costs of China supporting the Russian war

  • The U.S. will “impose costs” if Beijing backs Russia

Lull in micro data over the next 2 or 3 weeks

  • Unless there are pre-announcements over the next 2 weeks, investors are entering a lull in new data points and information

Q4 earnings had very few negative updates:

  • Main micro issues were margins, highlighting costs, supply chain and pricing power

  • Main macro issues were Europe recession fears, China Covid cases ticking up and oil’s rip to $120

Q1 earnings will start in 3 weeks

  • In the meantime, we will likely trade on macro data and geopolitical issues

Crude  102   (flat)

  • No real change in geopolitical overnight

  • Yesterday oil prices bounced from their pre-Ukraine invasion price

Earnings

  • FedEx

Crypto

  • Argentina’s Senate to vote on IMG letter of intent that would discourage cryptocurrency use

  • Maturing: Bitcoin implied volatility has been trending lower for months

  • Bitcoin has been stuck in a range all year but is tightening and forming a wedge:

QUICK HITS FROM GRIT

SIX things you need to know this week in 60 seconds.

  1. It’s hiking season

  2. Can private equity revive Nielsen Holdings?

  3. Live look-in at hedge funds

  4. Oil market volatility

  5. Ukraine & El Salvador embrace crypto in their own ways

  6. AMC buys a gold mine…wait what?

If you’re reading this but haven’t subscribed, join our community of +XXk smart, fun & edgy investors 👇

Subscribe now

1. MACRO

It’s hiking season

The Fed approved the first interest rate hike since December 2018 with just one dissenting vote in (surprise!) James Bullard who was pushed for 50 basis points.

Officials indicated rate increases at each of the six remaining meetings, which points to a consensus funds rate of 1.9% by the end of the year.

The committee is also increasing its inflation outlook (read: realizing it’s not so transitory) while dropping expectations for economic growth.

In the press conference following the meeting, Fed Chair Powell suggested that we could see quantitative tightening (QT) as soon as May.

GRIT’S TAKE: Meanwhile, producer prices increased at a slightly slower pace in February, but remain at 10% YoY which is the highest since records began in 2010.

GRIT’S ACTION: Long Stocks. Not touching bonds

Under the Radar

SCALING ACROSS MULTIPLE BLOCKCHAINS. As it looks to continue its rapid growth, Liquid Meta is building out the tech it needs to operate across multiple blockchains. The Meta Bridge platform is a simple and automatic way of deploying liquidity not only efficiently, but securely, by mitigating the risks of being hacked*!

EXPOSURE TO EXPLOSIVE MARKETS. Blockchain Foundry is at the forefront of innovation in the blockchain and NFT markets. From helping enterprises with opportunity audits, consulting, DeFi, token service to a custom-built NFTGen pipeline that will enable much more than what is offered with your typical NFTs, Blockchain Foundry is the gateway to the decentralized universe*.

INVEST IN THE METAVERSE. How are you getting exposure to the metaverse and NFTs in the stock market? Looking Glass Labs provides shareholders with both! Its wholly owned subsidiary, House of Kibaa, is building a hyper-realistic metaverse while its NFT drops with perpetual royalties generate consistent, passive revenue*!

CARBON CREDIT TOKENIZATION. By leveraging the power of the blockchain, DeepMarkit is transforming the way investors and project developers access the growing voluntary carbon credit market. Its proprietary platform, MintCarbon.io, is powered by the low-emission Polygon network and enables offset holders to mint their credits into NFTs, which can be listed for trading on decentralized exchanges globally. A unique revenue-sharing model also positions DeepMarkit for growth*!

*This is sponsored advertising content.
2. DEALS

Can private equity revive Nielsen Holdings?

Industry experts estimate there will be around 55 million cord-cutters in 2022. This isn’t surprising considering the rise of streaming services like Netflix, Disney+, Hulu, and hundreds of others vying for a spot in monthly budgets.

But while most are shouting “cable is dead”, Elliot Management and Brookfield Asset Management appear to be taking the other side of that bet as they close in on a $15B takeover of TV ratings group Nielsen Holdings.

It would be the largest such deal since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and it could be announced within a week.

Nielsen’s core business is measuring ad reach on cable/broadcast television—could offering services to streaming companies be next?

GRIT’S TAKE: This is the latest in a recent string of big leveraged buyouts, with PE firms shrugging off increasing financing costs—due to rising interest rates and greater volatility—as they look to deploy large amounts of accumulated cash.

GRIT’S ACTION: Cigar Butt investing at its finest (Buffett loves this style!). Cigar butts may be worth little, but if you can pay even less than "little," you might still get a few puffs out of them.

3. STOCK MARKET

Live look-in at hedge funds:

The Nasdaq popped into official bear market territory for a cup of coffee before posting back-to-back-to-back gains to head into the bell this morning.

Last week we noted that hedge funds have been deleveraging from equities. A Barclays report confirms that gross leverage fell to its lowest level in at least a year in February.

The first week of March also saw the third-highest amount of hedge fund selling for a 5-day period ever. The two larger periods? The meme-stock mania in January 2021 and the onset of lockdowns in March 2020.

Over that period, hedge funds dumped technology and consumer stocks faster than any time in the past decade.

GRIT’S TAKE: “This has become a ‘nowhere to hide’ market.” - Charlie McElligott, Nomura stategist.

GRIT’S ACTION: The average 1-year move for the NASDAQ after entering a bear market is a gain of 13%. This ain’t no dotcom bust. Most people can’t operate their day without the big 5 FAANG. LONG!

4. COMMODITIES

Oil market volatility

Volatility knows no bounds these days and the oil market is no exception.

On Monday (just sevens days after topping $130 a barrel), US oil prices dipped below $100 for the first time since February amid peace talks between Russia/Ukraine, as well as concerns around how new Covid lockdowns in China will affect demand.

Prices climbed yesterday after the International Energy Agency (IEA) announced the market could lose 3 million barrels per day of Russian products next month.

The resulting supply crunch is expected to be far greater than the demand loss from higher prices.

GRIT’S TAKE: Oil markets were mostly indifferent to the Fed’s interest rate hike this week.

GRIT’S ACTION: I WiLl NoT ChAsE EnErGy.

5. CRYPTO

Ukraine & El Salvador embrace crypto in their own ways

This week, while fighting off an invading army with one arm, Ukrainian President Zelenskyy used the other to sign “On Virtual Assets” and legalize cryptocurrency assets in the country. What can’t this guy do!?

To date, Ukraine has received ~$100M in crypto donations meant to aid in the effort to defend against Russia. The bill defines what is considered a crypto asset and establishes regulations around the industry.

Meanwhile, Salvadorean President Nayib Bukele is praying betting that his new 10-year “volcano bond” will help fund the country’s repayment and/or refinancing of expiring debt.

Bukele hopes to raise at least $1B from sales of the bond—which are issued by geothermal energy company La Geo on the Bitfinix platform—to increase its Bitcoin stock and finance a “bitcoin city” powered by geothermal energy from a nearby volcano (oh, and also to help repay that debt we mentioned, of course!).

GRIT’S TAKE: “Shooters shoot.” -President Nayib Bukele (probably)

GRIT’S ACTION: 5 year BITCOIN chart looks very bullish. Convince me otherwise!

6. ENTERTAINMENT

AMC buys a gold mine…wait what?

This week AMC (movie theatre chain) purchased a 22% stake in Nevada gold and silver miner Hycroft Mining for close to $28M.

CEO Adam Aron was scheduled to appear on CNBC Tuesday morning to discuss the self-described “bold diversification move” but canceled, citing stock volatility after the news sent Hycroft Mining shares on a meme-like run.

Investors and analysts alike—who by now are surely used to Aron’s shenanigans which include accepting Dogecoins, offering NFTs, and not wearing pants on Zoom calls—are understandably stumped by acquisition which lies so clearly outside of its core competencies.

GRIT’S TAKE: Connect the dots: Hycroft was taken public via Mudrick Capital Acquisition which is tied to Jason Mudrick whose firm Mudrick Capital Management pumped $100M into AMC in December 2020 to help bail them out of potential bankrupcty.

GRIT’S ACTION: Want to know if I am THUMBS UP or DOWN on AMC stock? Watch at 14:44!

Unusual Options Activity: ContextLogic Inc. (WISH)

*SOURCES
1. CNBC, WSJ
2. FT
3. FT
4. CNBC, Reuters
5. FT, Decrypt
6. CNBC

How does inflation affect stocks?

1990s     18.1%        6.7%

MARKET UPDATE

FED

  • Raises interest rates by a quarter point

  • 1st increase since 2018

  • Signals plans to lift rates steadily this year and next to lower inflation

item.title: Oil is the New Data
item.description: Commodity Crisis: Oil's Rampage, Nickel Halted, Wheat Offline
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Roch-Decter, CFA
item.content:encoded:
Hi Everyone 👋,

Welcome to the subscribers who have joined this week. If you’re reading this but haven’t subscribed, join our community of +55k smart, fun & edgy investors 👇

Subscribe now

*This is sponsored advertising content.

Oh and if you didn’t catch me throwing up Diamond Hands-on LIVE TV Friday here it is:

Now, let’s get into it!

Commodities are on an absolute tear.

Within the span of one day last week, the US put a ban on Russian oil & nat gas imports, Ukraine President Zelenskyy announced he would no longer look to join NATO, and Russia banned exports of raw materials (vague wording at the time).

Is Russia really going to cut off Europe from O&G? This could get wild…

In an increasingly hostile environment, countries are becoming more and more engaged in economic warfare through sanctions.

The globalization of trade that has been carefully built and fostered over the post-war Era is now being ripped to shreds in the span of weeks.

We’ve figured out how to get millions of tonnes of raw materials around the globe several times over. We’ve done this by extracting necessary resources to power great advances in the quality of life and technological breakthroughs to make the world more open than it has ever been before.

But we are still subjects to the folly of human nature whereby the betterment of all takes a back seat to the pursuits of self-interest.

Last week I wrote about the weaponization of currency. This week is all about the weaponization of commodities.

This week, in <5 minutes, we’ll cover the commodity market boom:

  • Comparative Advantage 👉 Gretzky vs. Joe

  • Import/Export Web 👉 Who trades what with who?

  • The Energy Complex 👉 Underinvestment straining geopolitics

  • Apparently Wheat is a Thing 👉 Worldwide dominant producers of goods make sense during globalization, not war

  • Guess that Chart 👉 Not a shitcoin…

1. Comparative Advantage 👉 Gretzky vs. Joe

In an increasingly globalized economy, we are more and more connected which opens the door for the concept of comparative competitive advantage.

For some reason, there is this one economics lesson that I can replay the exact image of what was on the chalkboard and what the professor was saying that day. I probably didn’t tune out during this lecture because of the analogy he used.

Comparative advantage is a concept that refers to the ability to produce goods and services at a lower opportunity cost, not necessarily at a greater volume or quality. You can have an absolute advantage, but a smaller player in the system can have the comparative advantage.

The analogy my professor used that day was between Wayne Gretzky and a landscaper named Joe. Let’s measure utility in this case by “smiles on faces.” Entertaining hockey puts smiles on faces. Freshly mowed lawns also put smiles on faces.

Surely “The Great One” could go out and mow lawns all day and plaster smiles on faces around his neighbourhood, but that is not his advantage. Gretzky scores goals for breakfast. This is what he is good at.

So to - Joe can perfectly edge a freshly cut lawn in his New Balance shoes far better than Gretzky ever could. Mowing lawns is what he is good at.

Every time Gretzky is mowing a lawn or Joe is trying to play hockey, faces are being robbed of smiles because that is not the optimal solution.

The opportunity cost is too high when Gretzky is mowing a lawn or when Joe is trying to score goals instead of vice versa. By introducing free-market globalized trade (the currency in this case: smiles), Gretzky and Joe together can increase the total amount of smiles generated by sticking to what they are relatively better at.

The same lies true for global trade. When the trade gates are open - why not produce what your country has a competitive advantage in and stick to it? But what happens when the trade gates close (sanctions)?

Gretzky now has to score goals and mow lawns.

Under the Radar

PUTTING THE WORLD FIRST. The mission is lofty, badass, but beautifully simple: get millions to rethink their food choices while helping them do the world a world of good. With constant innovation and R&D, Very Good Food is reinventing what’s possible in the fast-growing plant-based food sector, which means this game-changing business won’t be undervalued for long*!

SIGNIFICANT UPSIDE, NO DILUTION. With over $2B in projects including a $480M real estate project, a $550M solar project in Alberta, and a $1B+ solar project in the Caribbean, Greenbriar Capital is the most undervalued company in the real estate, ESG, and solar energy universe*!

CELLULAR AGRICULTURE INVESTING. Access to cellular agriculture startups is currently limited to ultra-high net worth individuals and private venture funds. CULT Food Science is on a mission to change that by becoming North America’s first mainstream cellular agriculture investment platform. The platform currently consists of 15 portfolio companies that represent the future of food*!

ONLINE GAMBLING IS COMING TO CANADA. Already the most engaged brand in esports betting globally, Rivalry averaged +22% MoM growth in 2021. As one of the first three companies to be fully registered for internet gaming and sports betting in Canada (and recently licensed in Australia), the Company is now poised to accelerate its growth in regulated markets*.

MUSHROOM MILESTONE ALERT! 🚨 Novamind announced big news this week: they’re conducting a phase II psilocybin trial for major depressive disorder sponsored by the Usona Institute.⁠ Read about it here.

DIGITAL HEALTHCARE REVOLUTION. CloudMD is an integrated healthcare platform built to scale. With a $185M revenue run rate and a cash position of $60M, it's well positioned as a leader in the digital healthcare space! Its network already covers over 5M lives, 5,500 employer clients, and more than 7,500 mental health professionals and the Company has partnered with some significant players like Sun Life, Accenture, Empire Life and Medavie Blue Cross to name a few*.

2. Import/Export Web 👉 Who trades what with who?

Last week, I put out a note that included a lot of trading maps around the import and export of Russian goods that you can find here. Since no one actually clicks through a link, here is a brief recap:

  • Russia’s exports are extremely concentrated. Roughly 60% of Russia’s exports are Crude based energy products.

  • The main destinations for these exports are the EU and China. European countries account for over 50% of exports while China accounts for 14%.

  • Russia’s imports are extremely diversified. Top import categories are machinery, transportation, and chemical products - a lot of goods that power the “real” consumer economy, and Russia can’t make them themselves.

  • The main sources of these imports are the EU and China. European countries account for over 50% of imports while China accounts for 20%.

  • There is a large amount of dependency in Europe on Crude imports.

So it’s clear that Russia has a relative competitive advantage in energy from the rest of Europe and you can see that through trade and how heavily relied upon it is across Europe.

What if Russia pinches the hose? Can Europe get it from somewhere else?

Before we continue, let’s check in with our Outrageous Chartered FinMEME Analyst Dr. Patel!

3. The Energy Complex 👉 Underinvestment straining geopolitics

Unless you’re living under a rock, you are well aware by now of the crusade of ESGers against fossil fuels. As this echoed up the chain of command, large capital allocators were stepping away altogether from anything to do with Oil & Gas.

What this resulted in was a drastic retreat in CAPEX spending by energy companies on drilling new wells. According to the EIA, the number of producing wells in the United States reached a high of 1,029,588 wells in 2014 and steadily declined to 936,934 wells in 2020 — mostly because of lower oil prices and less rig activity.

This drastic underinvestment is now being brought to light through the stress of sanctions on the overall system.

While the above tells the story of the western world, the US does not export a large amount of crude products over to Europe. So what’s up with the power balance over there?

The reality for renewables is that we’re just not there yet. Not enough capacity has been built out to keep up with demand - especially rising demand as the world opens back up from shutdowns.

The European Commission published plans on Tuesday to cut EU dependency on Russian gas by two-thirds this year and end its reliance on Russian supplies of the fuel “well before 2030.”

Exactly when and how this will happen will be critical.

4. Apparently Wheat is a Thing 👉 Worldwide dominant producers of goods make sense during globalization, not war

Russia and Ukraine supply 25% of the world’s wheat exports. What happens when these two countries are deep in conflict with heavy sanctions on the way? Price spikes…

Ukraine is renowned as the breadbasket of Europe, thanks in part to its nutrient-rich “black earth” soils. But its key wheat-growing regions and ports lie in Ukraine’s south and east, putting them close to Russian-held territory.

We are already well aware of how Covid supply chain issues have caused inflation. This will add even more pricing pressure as sanctions and wheat infrastructure vulnerability in Russia & Ukraine will increase food prices.

When Russia annexed Crimea in 2014, concerns about the disruption of supplies from the Black Sea breadbasket drove wheat prices up around 25% in two months. When little disruption occurred, prices reversed course. 

Time will tell on the staying power of this move this time around.

5. Guess that Chart 👉 Not a shitcoin…

There is a lot that happened behind the scenes with this one that is still being uncovered including a major short squeeze, bringing PTSD back to the days of hedge funds vs. WallStBets.

Guess the chart…

No, not a shitcoin cryptocurrency, this is the price chart for Nickel.

Prices went absolutely parabolic on Tuesday, forcing the London Metal Exchange to step in and halt trading.

Russia accounted for roughly 9.2% of the world’s total nickel mine production in 2021 and holds 7.5M tonnes of the metal in reserves. If Russia ends up moving forward with harsh commodity export bans, there will be a drastic undersupply of the metal in the market.

Nickel is heavily used in electric vehicle batteries - unless they were also hedged, this will drastically squeeze margins for producers of EVs.

Adding fuel to the fire was a short squeeze. But this one was different. Short positions can be laid on by speculators and those are what usually make headlines when a brash hedge fund goes after a poorly managed company.

Short positions can also be entered by producers of goods in order to protect against a potential price decrease. Producers will enter a contract to sell the commodity (short position) at a specific price, locking in that price on the delivery date.

However, if you are short these contracts, there comes a point where the position can become deeply negative, forcing a margin call where you have to cover some of the position which results in drastic price movement in a less liquid market.

This is exactly what happened to Tsingshan Holding Group, a large Chinese nickel company that had a paper loss that stood at $8 Billion before the exchange halted.

Bloomberg reported that on Wednesday Tsingshan secured new loans and credit lines from lenders including JPMorgan and China Construction Bank to help address the liquidity issue caused by the margin calls.

We’ll see how this one shapes out.

Wrapping Up…

In the past half of a century, the world has been steadily moving towards globalization that has been supercharged by both government and technological advancements.

While the technological advancements continue, we are now in a period of extended conflicts where governments are shutting off trade.

We hit the first hurdle when Covid shut down entire businesses and ports, but the pandemic was at least a united front whereby governments stepped in and created massive monetary stimulus to provide a safety net against a common enemy.

Conflict, however, is a completely different story. It pits many different actors in the closed system directly against each other. The current weapon of choice is sanctions, and this will cripple economies that are heavily reliant on certain imports.

Subscribe to my PAID newsletter to find out how I am investing (or not investing) during these volatile times!

Until next time. Always Yours. Incessantly Chasing ROI,

-Genevieve Roch-Decter, CFA

P.S. Have you subscribed to our *NEW* CRYPTO NEWSLETTER?

GRIT CRYPTO

#1 FREE Finance Newsletter on Substack. GRIT launches a PAID CRYPTO newsletter. After reaching a record $3 trillion in 2021, the market has pulled back ~40%. We believe NOW is the BEST time to go hunting for opportunities!
By Genevieve Roch-Decter, CFA

What else we Grittin’ On?

JOLTS. Demand for workers remained close to a record high with 11.3M job openings in January. Down only slightly from 11.4M in February.

BIG TECH ACQUISITION. Google buys cyber security Mandiant for $5.4B. This will be the company's second-largest acquisition ever.

MEME STOCK ACTIVITY. Chewy co-founder Ryan Cohen reveals 9.8% stake in Bed Bath & Beyond. Cohen also serves as chairman of meme-stock OG GameStop.

DISNEY PLOTS NEW GAMBLE. Disney is exploring ways to leverage its ESPN brand in the sports betting industry. The network hit peak subscribers in 2011.

INSTITUTIONAL CRYPTO ADOPTION. Crypto exchange giant FTX launches a division to cater to institutional investors seeking crypto exposure. It's time to go bargain hunting!

item.title: All eyes on FED meeting next week...
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Roch-Decter, CFA
item.content:encoded:
*This is sponsored advertising content.

Happy Friday Everyone! 👋

Remember, since 1900 the U.S dollar has lost 98% of its purchasing power. Meanwhile, the S&P has returned 315,853% inflation-adjusted.

Not owning stocks is risky.

MARKET UPDATE

  • FED meeting next week

  • Market expectations: Not Volcker

Rates

  • Big shift in market expectations after yesterday’s inflation print.

  • Market now pricing in a +60% probability of 8 rate hikes this year, which would bring the FED funds rate up to 2-2.25% by year end.

6:30 a.m. Putin: talks are “constructive” with Ukraine

  • “there are certain positive developments, as far as negotiators from our side informed me”

  • At the same time, Russia launched attacks on Western Ukraine for the first time

  • Finland’s president is scheduled to speak with Putin today after speaking with Zelensky earlier

  • Crude and Wheat are down on the news

Russia/Ukraine

  • Biden set to call an end of normal trade relations with Russia

  • This would put Russia in the company of Cuba and North Korea

Crude $105

  • What is the positive shift from Putin’s point of view?

  • Probably, it’s that Ukraine is not getting into NATO

  • Iran Nuclear deal talks have been suspended for now

Earnings

  • Oracle

  • Rivian

  • Ultra Beauty

  • DocuSign         -18%

  • WeWork

Crypto

  • Crypto markets haven’t been able to hold recent rallies

  • Russian based crypto volume remains high

  • Bitcoin pull/call ratio has come down from last month

  • And implied volatility is creeping up

QUICK HITS FROM GRIT

SIX things you need to know this week in 60 seconds.

  1. I guess we’re just walking everywhere now

  2. Carbon-transformer will test SPAC waters

  3. Retail buys the dip, Wall Street just dips

  4. The cost of everything is up

  5. Busy week for crypto off the field

  6. From the founder of r/WallStreetBets: the “Insider Portfolio”

If you’re reading this but haven’t subscribed, join our community of smart, fun & edgy investors 👇

Subscribe now

1. MACRO

I guess we’re just walking everywhere now

The national average for gas at the pump is $4.318 a gallon. That’s the highest since 2008 (although in today’s dollar, gas was $5.31 in June 2008).

For months oil prices had already been rallying as the global economy rebounded from the pandemic on lower output levels than before.

As one of the world’s biggest oil producers, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine caused a global supply shock that sent Brent over $130 this week.

Biden has said he would release millions of barrels from the US Strategic Petroleum Reserve, but it’s not expected to make a material impact on prices at the pump.

GRIT’S TAKE: The White House—after banning Russian oil and gas—is now discussing the possibility of replacing Russian imports with supply from some not-so-great sources, like Venezuela and Iran.

GRIT’S ACTION: Not chasing this energy trade. “The cure for high oil prices, is high oil prices”

Under the Radar

THE INFRASTRUCTURE POWERING DeFi. Decentralized Finance (DeFi) is taking over the finance world, but it still remains a mystery to many. That’s why Liquid Meta is building the bridge from TradFi to DeFi which will enable equal access to financial products & services to all individuals & businesses around the world*.

EXPOSURE TO EXPLOSIVE MARKETS. Blockchain Foundry is at the forefront of innovation in the blockchain and NFT markets. From helping enterprises with opportunity audits, consulting, DeFi, token service to a custom-built NFTGen pipeline that will enable much more than what is offered with your typical NFTs, Blockchain Foundry is the gateway to the decentralized universe*.

INVEST IN THE METAVERSE. How are you getting exposure to the metaverse and NFTs in the stock market? Looking Glass Labs provides shareholders with both! Its wholly owned subsidiary, House of Kibaa, is building a hyper-realistic metaverse while its NFT drops with perpetual royalties generate consistent, passive revenue*!

*This is sponsored advertising content.
2. DEALS

Carbon-transformer will test SPAC waters

LanzaTech is one of many companies developing technologies to decarbonize high-emitting industries through capture and reuse.

The Chicago-based “carbon-capture and transformation” technology firm traps carbon emitted during industrial processes and then turns it into sustainable chemicals and products—such as ethanol—using bacteria.

Manufacturers like steelmakers will use LanzaTech technology in their manufacturing process to reduce their environmental footprints, and companies like Unilever and Coty are buyers of the resulting end products.

The company will be testing the choppy open SPAC waters soon after announcing this week a $2.2B merger with SPAC AMCI Acquisition Corp. II.

GRIT’S TAKE: CNBC’s SPAC Post Deal Index, which is comprised of SPACs that have completed mergers and gone public, is down 56% YoY.

GRIT’S ACTION: Carbon might buck the trend. I have seen at least 6 carbon deals hit my desk in the last couple of weeks. Institutional appetite is strong!

3. STOCK MARKET

Retail buys the dip, Wall Street just dips

This generation of retail investors’ strategy can be summed up with 4 words, or just 4 letters, really: BTFD.

The retail army held strong this week, pouring $1.51B into equities on Monday despite a massacre that saw the S&P and Nasdaq drop nearly 3% and 4%, respectively.

Since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, retail investors have bought roughly $12B worth of dip. Hold the chips.

On the other hand, we’re seeing hedge funds deleveraging from equities.

While the risk of capitulation remains, hedge-fund positioning has become so bearish that the risk-reward of holding equities is skewed to the upside.

- Ben Onatibia and Giacomo Pierantoni, Vanda Research

GRIT’S TAKE: The level of active deleveraging is the biggest aside from March 2020 (pandemic) and January 2021 (GameStop).

GRIT’S ACTION: Adding to my core “sleep-at-night” portfolio. Volatility is an opportunity.

4. COMMODITIES

The cost of everything is up

The geopolitical wake of Russia’s invasion has propelled both the Bloomberg Commodity Spot Index and the UN’s global food index to record highs.

Grain markets are skyrocketing, led by wheat which peaked at a record $12.94 per bushel this week (Russia produces 11% of the world’s wheat is and is the largest exporter).

Peter Schiff is living his best life with gold getting above that pesky $2k mark for the first time in 18 months.

The price of nickel surged 250% over 2 days this week to briefly top $100k per ton, prompting the London Metal Exchange to suspend trading and investors to check between the couch cushions for loose change.

Oil volatility remains with Brent crossing above $130 a barrel briefly before coming back down, potentially on concerns over demand destruction.

GRIT’S TAKE: There’s no sugarcoating it: the future is going to cost more money.

GRIT’S ACTION: Own stocks with pricing power. Banks & Tech.

5. CRYPTO

Busy week for crypto off the field

Biden finally announced his crypto executive order this week: Ensuring Responsible Development of Digital Assets. It will task federal agencies to produce reports on and consider new regulations for digital currencies. It will also explore the possibility of creating a digital version of the USD.

The biggest hedge fund names—like Alan Howard and Paul Tudor Jones—are also expanding their crypto investments. With crypto markets large and liquid enough to be tradeable, mainstream hedge funds are now seeing crypto as a fifth asset class.

It’s not a hedge fund, but this week Bain Capital launched a $560M fund (with a tone-deaf announcement!) that will invest in mainly crypto-focused infrastructure and DeFi by assembling a portfolio of 30 new companies or protocols.

GRIT’S TAKE: All of this points to increased institutional adoption! Coinbase reported $1.14T of crypto trading from institutions last year which is more than double the $535B that individual investors traded.

GRIT’S ACTION: After a pullback of ~40%, we believe NOW is the best time to go hunting for alt-coins! Subscribe to GRIT’s *NEW* crypto newsletter to follow us on this journey!

6. ENTERTAINMENT

From r/WallStreetBets: the “Insider Portfolio”

Nancy Pelosi and her husband are reported to have made as much as $30MM over the last decade on investments in companies the lawmaker is responsible for regulating.

Whether it’s call options on Nvidia or leaps on Tesla, you really can’t go wrong by following the Senator’s path when it comes to picking stocks.

That’s why the founder of r/WallStreetBets is pitching the “Insider Portfolio” which—with the help of our friends at Unusual Whales—tracks and mimics trades made by Pelosi and her husband.

The product can be found for $1 a share on an obscure exchange called MERJ based on an island off East Africa and is only available to investors who use the WallStreetBets app (there’s an app!?).

This is where a big NOT FINANCIAL ADVICE stamp would typically go.

GRIT’S TAKE: Unfortunately this fund might be dead in the water as multiple bills are being considered to ban members of Congress from trading stocks, which means WallstreetBets is going to have to go back to doing things the old fashion way: pumping meme stocks!

GRIT’S ACTION: If it sounds too good to be true… it usually is!

What stocks are trending in the news?

*SOURCES
1. CNBC
2. WSJ
3. Bloomberg, MarketEar
4. Reuters, Bloomberg, Bloomberg, Axios
5. WSJ, Blockworks, WSJ
6. NY Post

Good Morning Everyone!

Remember over the last year:

Meanwhile, your bank account is only up +0.06%.

You can’t just save. You must invest.

MARKET UPDATE

Russia/Ukraine talks in Turkey made little progress

  • +7.9% Y/Y

10yr Yield

  • 1.98% call it 2% which is a 1-year high

Crude  $114

  • Announced faster winding down of QE

Crypto

  • Biden signed Executive Order on Ensuring Responsible Development of Digital Assets

BONUS: GRIT’S First Crypto Newsletter

item.title: Yesterday was ugly.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Roch-Decter, CFA
item.content:encoded:
*This is sponsored advertising content

Good Morning Everyone!

Remember, the longer you hold the greater the potential for high returns. From 1937-2020, here's how often stocks were up based on the holding period:

1 yr 👉 76%

5 yrs 👉 90%

10 yrs 👉 97%

Lesson? Buy great companies and ignore the noise.

MARKET UPDATE

Yesterday was ugly.

  • Growth slowdown. NASDAQ Bear Market

  • Fundamentals mattering less and less

  • WTI Oil hit $120, up another 3.6%

  • U.S. pump prices hit $4 / gallon.

  • As commodity prices surge, it weighs on household budgets.

  • In Europe more so than the U.S.

Going into today’s trading:

  • Nasdaq            down 21% from highs (technical Bear Market)

  • S&P 500          down 13%

  • TSX                  close to all-time highs!

  • US Dollar: New High

Volatility: VIX @35

  • As volatility climbs, hedge funds continue to de-leverage

Crude  $125 (+5%)

  • U.S. will announce ban on Russian oil without allies

  • This would be a symbolic gesture

  • U.S. imports from Russia account for only 5% of Russian production

  • Venezuelan President Maduro has agreed to continue negotiations with the U.S.

  • Blinken said Russia continues to create roadblocks to an Iran Nuclear deal

  • Russia, Venezuela, Iran………..

  • It’s a mystery why we still have no word from Biden on Keystone XL or Alaska?

  • Alberta Premier Kenney said if Biden were to approve, Keystone ready Q1 2023

  • Keystone would increase oil-sands export by 900,000 barrels a day

  • This is all you need to know: month-to-date Oil up 30% and its only March 8

Other commodities are quieter today

  • Except for a 70% spike in Nickel on short covering

  • LME suspended trading on the spike

Food crisis?

  • Wheat is up 77% in 2022 to $13.63 a bushel

European Union

  • Considering a plan to jointly issue bonds

  • To finance accelerated energy and defense spending

  • Hope is Europe will seek to reduce its dependency on Russian for oil and gas

  • It appears that some (only some) Russian production is stranded which is why oil is so strong

Used Car pricing finally going DOWN

  • February pricing up 36% YoY, but down 2% MoM

  • Full size cars, compact cars, luxury cars, pickups all down

  • EV cap prices were flat month-over-month

In other Auto news, Auto supplies getting hit!

  • Schaeffler Group (Europe) suspended 2022 guidance amid Ukraine uncertainties

  • Impossible to predict effects on supply chains, freight rates, raw materials

  • Auto supplier stocks getting close to Covid Panic March 2020 relative lows

GRIT STOCKS:

Google

  • Announces intent to buy Mandiant for $23/share in cash

  • For Google, second largest deal ever

  • I love it, CASH !

  • $5.4 billion, 57% premium

  • Mandiant provides cyber defense solutions

  • Cybersecurity more important in big Tech to respond to online threats

Apple

  • New product event today

Earnings          None

  • Crypto

  • Biden will issue executive order on crypto this week

    • Will direct federal agencies to evaluate potential regulatory changes, national security, and economic impact of digital assets

    • “I want to be on the side of the innovator” - Oregon Senator Ron Wyden (chair of Senate Finance Committee) on stricter crypto regulations

  • Coinbase blocks >25k addresses linked to illicit Russian activity

MEME OF THE DAY

Unusual Options Activity: JD.com

Genevieve’s Actions

Major Portfolio Changes in January?

Large Cap Public:

ADDS:

·     Microsoft (MSFT, $2.2T). Microsoft reported stellar earnings growth at massive scale, particularly in their cloud business. Ignore headlines about “growth slowing in cloud” MSFT on a currency-adjusted basis grew azure 50% YoY in the quarter. Last 4 quarters: 50%, 51%, 48%, 50%

SELLS:

·     First Quantum (FM, C$22B). The sell here is driven by taking profits on the recent run in all cyclical stocks.

item.title: The Weaponization of Money
item.description: How SWIFT, Reserve Currency, and Sanctions are being used to Handcuff Russia
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Roch-Decter, CFA
item.content:encoded:
Hi Everyone 👋,

Welcome to the subscribers who have joined this week. If you’re reading this but haven’t subscribed, join our community of smart, fun & edgy investors 👇

Subscribe now

*This is sponsored advertising content.

Everything has a cost.

Some are direct - like the price tag on the clothes you buy. Some are hidden - like sleepless nights as a new parent.

Either way, you have to pay a price for everything.

When an invasion through needless acts of aggression threatens the post cold war era of peace, tragically, a price is already being paid by both sides.

The tangible prices of war are civilian lives, guns, ammunition, tanks, and fighter jets. The intangible prices are fear, terror, and despair.

The tangible mediums of aggression usually do not spawn alone from fierce nationalism but need to be financed through capital in order to be obtained. Someone needs to pay for the war machine to run.

Choking the funding source will limit the resources available.

The ultimate fight against tyranny is refusing to be a bystander in an ever-connected global social economy. Imposing sanctions is a good start - but even further measures are now being taken.

There are numerous headlines about the globally organized “weaponization of money” in order to stymie Russian advances.

This week, in <5 minutes, we’ll go over the weaponization of money:

  • State of Russian Economy Pre-Ukraine 👉 Major imports/exports, energy impact

  • Russian Economic Response 👉 SWIFT cutoff, Ruble plummets, Central bank doubling interest rates

  • How GRIT’s Playing It 👉 In a rising rate environment, stick to these names.

Let’s get started!

1. State of Russian Economy Pre-Ukraine 👉 Major imports/exports, energy impact

In order to understand how to best stifle the Russian attack, we need to understand what the state of the economy was leading into the invasion.

Russia is a commodity-driven economy, with its major exports broken down as follows:

The main takeaway here is energy dominant - and extremely concentrated. So we know a primary driver of their economy is exporting Oil & Gas, but who is it to?

Predominantly Europe (purple) and China. While we can look at this and say, “well let’s slow down major energy consumption from Russia in order to stifle their economy”, it’s not that straightforward. When we look at the reliance on natural gas, there is dependence on Russia:

As for major imports into Russia?

Very all over the map - the top ones being machinery (blue), transportation (light blue), and chemical products (pink). AKA a lot of goods that power the real economy. The main takeaway here is that imports are very diversified - and it doesn’t look like they can produce a lot of it themselves.

What countries are the main suppliers?

Again - Europe and China. What this all brings us to is the implementation of sanctions on imports and exports as an effective tool used to choke the Russian economy.

Limiting the number of imports into Russia robs them of essential goods needed for day-to-day activities. By limiting the amount of energy Russia is able to export, this even further weakens the current account balance as well as the ability of Putin’s oligarch cronies to pad their coffers.

The downside is that the citizens of Russia will be impacted in a massive way and do not support the actions of the Kremlin. Their life savings have much less purchasing power, and they will have trouble obtaining goods in a more and more inflationary environment. Both of these contribute to drastically lower purchasing power.

In an ever-connected global economy, the ripple effects of sanctions turn into tidal waves, and we’re seeing the most drastic effects on the energy economy…

Direct Impact on Energy Market

Many are likening the international backlash of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine to the 1970s Oil shocks when Iran went under a revolution at home and an asset freeze by the US government. Bloomberg’s gauge of raw materials was set for its biggest weekly gain since the 1960s as sanctions on Russia have now scared off all major buyers.

European nat gas broke price records and oil futures swung in the widest range in three decades. For those following GRIT on Instagram, I also highlighted these points:

The economy is more intertwined than ever, and further to the nat gas chart above, crude dependency in Europe on Russia is critical:

So we need to come up with viable alternatives for energy consumption away from Russia which is why everyone is scrambling right now.

A key method of exporting all the Crude that Russia produces is shipping, which accounts for 2/3rds of export volume. When there was a widespread inability to secure insurance or tankers, this caused a huge run on Brent crude futures, rising to $120 per barrel. Now there’s a JPM analyst out saying Oil is on track to hit $185 per barrel by the end of the year.

This prompted a response that included the first coordinated deployment of emergency oil reserves by members of the IEA in a decade.

As mentioned above Iran/Venezuela/Saudi Arabia could add capacity, but even Iran looks like a drop in the bucket compared to taking Russia offline.

It’s estimated the EU could reduce its nat gas imports by about 40%, but it would take years of disruptions to people’s everyday lives.

Lots of uncertainty still to come here…

Under the Radar

PUTTING THE WORLD FIRST. The mission is lofty, badass, but beautifully simple: get millions to rethink their food choices while helping them do the world a world of good. With constant innovation and R&D, Very Good Food is reinventing what’s possible in the fast-growing plant-based food sector, which means this game-changing business won’t be undervalued for long*!

LEADING FOOD INNOVATION. MeliBio, a CULT Food Science portfolio company, just received the JUST Food Magazine Excellence Award in the Innovation category! Previously, it was featured in TIME’s 2021 edition of “Top 100 Inventions of The Year”. And they’re not done yet: the bee-free honey-producing trailblazer is expanding production and hiring top scientists to develop delicious new flavors*!

ONLINE GAMBLING IS COMING TO CANADA. Already the most engaged brand in esports betting globally, Rivalry averaged +22% MoM growth in 2021. As one of the first three companies to be fully registered for internet gaming and sports betting in Canada (and recently licensed in Australia), the Company is now poised to accelerate its growth in regulated markets*.

DIGITAL HEALTHCARE REVOLUTION. CloudMD is an integrated healthcare platform built to scale. With a $185M revenue run rate and a cash position of $60M, it's well positioned as a leader in the digital healthcare space! Its network already covers over 5M lives, 5,500 employer clients, and more than 7,500 mental health professionals and the Company has partnered with some significant players like Sun Life, Accenture, Empire Life and Medavie Blue Cross to name a few*.

SUSTAINABILITY MARKETPLACE BUILT TO SCALE. In just 14 short months since launch, Vejii has shown tremendous growth and become a digital powerhouse in the plant-based and sustainable living space! With a marketplace built for rapid scale, it just reported record revenue for January with a YoY increase of over 1,100%*!

*This is sponsored advertising content.

2. Economic Sanctions👉 SWIFT cutoff, Ruble plummets, Central bank doubling interest rates

The U.S., EU, UK, Canada, Japan, and other countries have moved to delist certain Russian banks from the SWIFT financial transactions system.

SWIFT, formally known as the Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication, is a messaging system for banks and other financial institutions around the world. It doesn’t shuttle any money itself but provides instruction messages for just how to give and receive specific funds.

There are workarounds—the banks could use other messaging systems, such as apps or email—but those transactions likely won’t be as secure and could end up being slower and costing more. Overall - this is a great speedbump to put in place.

But the biggest hammer in the toolshed was next to come…

On Monday last week, the Biden administration imposed sanctions on Russia’s Central Bank that prohibit U.S. dollar-denominated transactions and are intended to largely wipe out Moscow’s $630 billion foreign currency war chest, which the Kremlin hoped would insulate the Russian economy from other sanctions Western nations have imposed.

Collectively, several financial sanctions aimed to freeze any remaining U.S.-based assets held by the Russian Central Bank in the United States or by Americans abroad.

Typically, what foreign reserves are used for is to prop up currencies in the event of massive adverse moves. After these reserves were frozen, the Ruble plummeted:

This led to the Russian central bank immediately doubling its interest rates in order to try to stop the bleeding.

A bank will increase the rates in order to entice capital into the country but when assets and the flow of goods get frozen altogether, the notion of interest rate price parity kind of goes right out the window.

This kind of makes me question what the point of holding foreign currency reserves is in the first place…

But first, let’s check in with our Outrageous Chartered FinMEME Analyst Dr. Patel!

3. How GRIT’s Playing It 👉 In a rising rate environment, stick to these names.

I do think that in a rising rate environment, banks are the way to play. As long as we can avoid major recession, the macro read-throughs particularly for Canadian banks, look promising.

For those following my paid newsletter, you’re aware that I recently added to my Royal Bank of Canada (RY-T) as well as Manulife (MFC-T). I like low-risk insurers in a rising rate environment (higher discount rate = lower liabilities). Q4 Beat EPS (strong asset management). Strong chart: stock poking its head above 13-year resistance ~$27. Next resistance = $34 / 40. Strong yield +5%.

Wrapping Up…

Supply chains don’t seem to be clearing up from Covid, now we have government-mandated sanctions and commodity prices are back to sky-rocketing. What this is going to lead to is a longer-term inflationary period which is 1) higher than we have experienced in the last few decades and 2) higher than we were initially expecting.

There is going to be a much more prolonged pressure to raise rates and at the same time avoid the dreaded “S” word… Stagflation (little to no growth and higher than normal inflation).

Long-tail black swan events galore.

Until next time. Always Yours. Incessantly Chasing ROI,

-Genevieve Roch-Decter, CFA

P.S. With the crypto market pulling back over 40% after reaching a new record of nearly $3 TRILLION in 2021, we believe NOW is the BEST time to go hunting for opportunities in the alt-coin market!

That’s why we’ve launched a new GRIT CRYPTO NEWSLETTER! Read the first issue here!

GRIT CRYPTO

#1 FREE Finance Newsletter on Substack. GRIT launches a PAID CRYPTO newsletter. After reaching a record $3 trillion in 2021, the market has pulled back ~40%. We believe NOW is the BEST time to go hunting for opportunities!
By Genevieve Roch-Decter, CFA

What else we Grittin’ On?

QUARTER-POINT HIKE. Fed Chair Jerome Powell backed a quarter-point interest rate hike at the Fed's next meeting. The Fed will meet on March 16.

SPAC TROUBLE. Dozens of companies that went public via SPAC missed 2021 revenue projections. By A LOT!

U.S. SHALE. You already know OPEC isn't boosting production but U.S. shale producers don't have plans to increase output in 2022. Make oil negative again!

CRYPTO ADOPTION. Wall Street traded $1.4T worth of cryptocurrency on Coinbase in 2021. That's up from $120B in 2020.

FORD GOES ELECTRIC. Ford Motor will create an electric vehicle & software division separate from its conventional gas-engine business. It expects EVs to account for 1/3 of sales by 2026.

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-03-05/russia-energy-chaos-triggers-the-biggest-market-shock-in-decades?srnd=premium

item.title: The world needs more barrels/commodities. Until then....hunker down.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Roch-Decter, CFA
item.content:encoded:
*This is sponsored advertising content.

Happy Friday Everyone! 👋

Remember, expect volatility and enjoy getting wealthy.

MARKET UPDATE

JOBS

  • Payrolls, added 678,000 positions in February vs. 423,000 estimate

  • Unemployment rate 3.8%

  • The labour market is very tight as the FED prepares to raise rates

Safety Trade = US dollar

  • 5 year high      102.8 on March 20, 2020 (Pandemic lock down)

  • Today              98.9

Crude  $111 (+3%)

  • Crude will record its biggest weekly surge in 2 years

  • European natural gas is back to its highs

  • Iran nuclear deal negotiations continue over the weekend

RUSSIA

  • There are no easy solutions right now

  • Russia exports 5% of the world’s crude oil

  • Russian exports 7% of global gas

  • Russia supplies 31% of Europe’s natural gas

  • There is not enough spare capacity in the world to make up for Russian exports

  • Total Russian exports lost is 5-6 million barrels

  • Iran could add 1.3 million

  • If we could work with Venezuela, it could add 2-3 million

  • Saudi Arabia has some spare capacity

  • Bottom Line – Russian oil is going to have to be consumed somewhere or we have $200 oil and a global recession

Wheat rising by the exchange limit to hit $12 bushel

  • 85% of Russia exports are commodities

Lumber

Copper

Earnings

  • Broadcom

  • Costco

  • Marvell

  • The Gap

Crypto

  • Ukraine will issue a collection of NFTs to raise funds to support its troops

  • Huge inflows in February for Bitcoin ETPs in Brazil and Canada

QUICK HITS FROM GRIT

SIX things you need to know this week in 60 seconds.

  1. Russian market goes down swift-ly

  2. Fanatics gets closer to IPO

  3. Amazon’s retail shift

  4. Oil tops $115

  5. Watershed moment for crypto

  6. Tracking Russian oligarchs

If you’re reading this but haven’t subscribed, join our community of smart, fun & edgy investors 👇

Subscribe now

1. MACRO

Russian market goes down swift-ly

The Russian market has seen better days. This week shares of MSCI Russia ETF pulled off a 16-sigma event—meaning, an event that should not happen even once in the history of the universe!

This happened after the US, Canada, and European allies cut off 7 Russian banks from SWIFT—the global interbank messaging system—over the weekend.

Russia’s central bank more than doubled its key interest rate from 9.5% to 20% in an effort to offset the “increased risk of ruble depreciation and inflation”.

The ruble remains at historic lows and the Russian stock market has been closed all week. MSCI and FTSE Russell plan to cut Russian equities from their benchmarks next week.

GRIT’S TAKE: The SWIFT ban stopped short of cutting off payments for vital Russian energy supplies.

GRIT’S ACTION: Long Bitcoin and not buying Russian stocks (not a value play yet).

Under the Radar

INVEST, DISRUPT, REPEAT. The cycle of disruption is spinning tighter than ever which means the tech giants of the next decade are being incubated as we speak. Digital health, gaming, Web3.0, crypto, VR/AR, AI, Creator Economy, and Metaverse. These are the cutting-edge technologies that are shaping the 4th Revolution of Intelligence and they happen to be right in Victory Square’s sweet spot. Investors get access to a diverse portfolio of over 20 disruptive startups across the industries of the future*!

EXPOSURE TO EXPLOSIVE MARKETS. Blockchain Foundry is at the forefront of innovation in the blockchain and NFT markets. From helping enterprises with opportunity audits, consulting, DeFi, token service to a custom-built NFTGen pipeline that will enable much more than what is offered with your typical NFTs, Blockchain Foundry is the gateway to the decentralized universe*.

INVEST IN THE METAVERSE. How are you getting exposure to the metaverse and NFTs in the stock market? Looking Glass Labs provides shareholders with both! Its wholly owned subsidiary, House of Kibaa, is building a hyper-realistic metaverse while its NFT drops with perpetual royalties generate consistent, passive revenue*!

*This is sponsored advertising content.
2. DEALS

Fanatics gets closer to IPO

In April 2021, 84-year old Topps announced it was going public via SPAC. By August it had abandoned those plans after the MLB broke off its 70-year old deal in favor of a younger, sexier partner.

By January 2022, that younger, sexier company had completed its utter domination of Topps after acquiring it for $500M.

This week, Fanatics continued its upward trajectory in the sports merchandising and memorabilia industry as it completed a $1.5B raise at a $27B valuation which has investors anticipating an inevitable IPO.

The company says the IPO is likely but won’t provide a timetable as the firm focuses on expanding its core business. It currently has exclusive trading-card deals with leagues like MLB, NBA, NFL, and NHL.

GRIT’S TAKE: To get those deals, Fanatics often had to get the leagues to overturn longstanding relationships, like the one between MLB and Topps.

GRIT’S ACTION: Your fans are everything. Build for them.

3. STOCK MARKET

Amazon’s retail shift

Amazon purchased Whole Foods in 2017 for over $13B. Since then, the company’s sales growth for its physical store unit has painfully lagged the overall retail business.

Its physical stores—including Whole Foods—reported more sales in 2018 than they did in 2021.

Now Amazon is shifting its focus in the physical retail world to grocery stores and the technology that powers them at other retail sites. It will be shutting down dozens of Amazon Books, Pop Ups, and 4-star stores (68 locations in total) as it looks to build on its cashier-less stores.

The company will seek to leverage innovations like the “Just Walk Out” technology it’s currently implementing in “Amazon Go” and conventional grocery stores, which include features like palm-scanning payments and shopping carts with sensors for checkout.

GRIT’S TAKE: A key concern here is that the cost of using this technology might be too high for the retail grocery industry which operates on slim margins.

GRIT’S ACTION: Long $AMZN, they have the free cash flow to pivot and thrive.

4. COMMODITIES

Oil tops $115

Russia is the world’s third-biggest oil producer but 70% of its crude is “struggling to find buyers” as big energy consumers are boycotting Russian oil.

The market is already tight, but typical buyers have “self-sanctioned” in an act of defiance towards the country’s actions against Ukraine, and it’s causing a race to secure alternative supplies.

To make matters worse, freight rates are spiking and war insurance premiums are causing some shipowners to turn down bookings.

Meanwhile, the price of oil has jumped to its highest level since 2011, but OPEC—which includes Russia—still sees no reason to it should make any changes to production.

GRIT’S TAKE: On Tuesday the US and others agreed to release 60M barrels from emergency stockpiles. This is widely considered far below what is needed to calm fears over the disruption of vital Russian supplies.

GRIT’S ACTION: Not buying energy stocks near the high.

5. CRYPTO

Watershed moment for crypto

Amid growing geopolitical uncertainty, Bitcoin has decoupled from traditional markets and trading activity is on the rise.

In Russia and Ukraine, trading volumes in Bitcoin have surged to the highest level since May and October, respectively.

Thousands of investors have donated millions in crypto to support Ukraine in what is being called the “world’s first crypto war”.

On Sunday, the vice prime minister of Ukraine asked major crypto exchanges to block Russian accounts. Binance, Kraken, and other big firms have condemned Russia’s actions but have said they will not “unilaterally freeze millions of innocent users’ accounts.”

GRIT’S TAKE: The “digital gold” argument for Bitcoin is looking much tighter than it was at the start of the year!

GRIT’S ACTION: Watch me on Meet Kevin tell 1.8M subscribers what I think about Bitcoin!

6. ENTERTAINMENT

Tracking Russian oligarchs

Last month we wrote about the Florida teenager who created a viral Twitter bot that tracked Elon Musk’s private jet.

Now, Jack Sweeney has set his sights on a new target: Russian oligarchs.

@RUOligarchJets and @Putinjet have 345k and 86k followers on Twitter, respectively, and they do exactly what you think: track roughly 40 planes and helicopters linked to Russian oligarchs who currently find themselves on the wrong end of severe global financial sanctions.

No word yet on whether any of the oligarchs have reached out to Sweeney in an attempt to negotiate.

GRIT’S TAKE: Regarding the Musk tracker (still operational), Sweeney says there’s an open offer on the table: a new Tesla Model 3 in exchange for deleting the account. The proverbial ball is in Musk’s court.

GRIT’S ACTION: People are creating DAOs to crowdfund and buy Russian oligarch’s assets on the cheap. LOL!

Unusual Options Activity: Nokia

*SOURCES
1. CNBC, MarketEar
2. WSJ
3. Reuters
4. FT
5. Bloomberg, CNBC
6. CNN

item.title: $100 Oil, Bitcoin, State of the Union 9pm
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Roch-Decter, CFA
item.content:encoded:
*This is sponsored advertising content

Good Morning Everyone!

Except Vladimir Putin.

MARKET UPDATE

  • Russia said: it would continue its operation in Ukraine until its goals are met

  • Troops near Kyiv

  • Russian stock market is closed for a second day

  • Vladimir Putin black belt has been revoked the international taekwondo organization

US

  • Biden State of the Union @ 9 p.m. tonight
